Pretty good but not fantastic.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2012 Reddish/Dark with little head and an aroma of fudge. Beautiful sweet fudge taste.  Slightly stronger alcohol taste to the standard version, but having tried both side-by-side, the flavors are not too noticably different.

Draught (GBBF2010)
Superb deep rich roasty aroma, a touch blackcurranty
4 Black, brief tan head.
8 Lovely rich and mellow roasted taste, cognac hints.
4 Rich and smooth, very burnt but not astringent. No hint of 11.5%. Warm, yes, but no heat.
15 Menno slots in another classic.

Bouteille verte de 180 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de caramel et de chocolat avec une pointe de vanille. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Saveur: Goût de chocolat avec une pointe de vanille et dhoublons. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de café en arrière goût. (Rating #3373)

180 ml bottle courtesy of a trade with yespr.  Pours a dark prune brown with a ring of off-white for a head.  The aroma is superb with caramel, molasses, oak, vanilla and dates.  The flavor is excellent as well with caramel, molasses, oak and port wine.  This is followed by some moderate alcohol warmth and some mild-moderate bitterness at the finish.  This is a lovely beer and my thanks again to yespr for sending this.

180cl bottle purchased in the netherlands (bottle 351 of 1216)... pours a dark cola brown, perhaps a tad darker, lighter at the edges and topped with a thin wispy film of light beige head... aroma seems as though it has a lot going on with hints of cocoa, roast, wet wood, and a whiskey like component.  the barrel is pretty assertive and there is a faint spice to it to boot.  a faint fruitiness surfaces within a fraction of the finish... flavors are sweet, rich, and dessert like with a moderate barrel presence.  molasses, some fair roast, and brown sugar mingle with the formerly mentioned barrel notes and maintaining that sweet composition.  body is thick and full which holds up to the strong flavor profile.  carbonation is present and at a good level.  the sweetness almost becomes overwhelming but is curtailed due to the small volume.  serving size is small but more than adequate for a couple of individuals. solid.

[3256-20100803] Wood cask sample. Alcoholic roast malt aroma has lots of roast. Black body with quick brown bubbles. Rich roast wood cask malt flavour has a lingering boozy grains aftertaste. Full boozy body. Bit rough but otherwise in good shape.
(@ GBBF 2010, London, England)

Aroma:whisky,chocolate,alcohol...
Appearance:dark lacing brown head...
Flavor:alcohol, rosted malt,Dark chocolate,light rasberries..

Bottle. Black body with a medium forever lasting light brown head. Aroma is lots of coffee, smoke, tobacco, roasted malt, dark fruit. Flavor is some kind of light sour berries, coffee, hops, dark fruit, roasted malt. The alcohol is well hidden. Nice lacings.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2010 Bottle @ home. Deep dark black pour, small tanned head.
Aroma is huge liquorice, big fruits, slight alcohol, chocolate, spices, wine/cognac.
Flavour intense roasty, chocolate, earth, wood, spices, thick sweetness, lingering bitterness. Some warmness from the alcohol.
Wicked, powerfull and very intense. A bit thinner than the original which keeps it from scoring higher.

180 ml bottle.  Dark brown with a tan haze.  Nose is carob, fudge brownie and chocolate liqueur.  Medium body with intense flavor saturation.  A sipper for sure.  Taste is honey sweetened coffee, dates and red currants.  Hints of tobacco, anise and fennel.  Finishes with a coffee buzz.  Wow, takes the imperial porter to another level.

Bottle #666, rating #4000. Black, brown layer.Toasted notes, chocolate, coffee, a hint bourbon.
Cherry pralines. port and/or sherry, coffebeans, bitter chocolate, light licorice, a hint fermenting fruit (durinlike). All flavours mesh very well together, great balance. 
Finishes on a whiskeylike burn, light cigars retronasal, licorice dryness on the tongue. 
Mellow, light sparkly,  chewy mouthfeel. A absolute pleasure - I am a little bit worried about the bottle number though ;-)

Cask at GBBF. Black with a brown head. Lovely oaky vanilla aroma, lots of maltiness, chocolate, bit of nuttiness, and port. Mouth is sweet, coffee, malty, some oak, dark fruit, chocolate. Slight tartness, but a fluffy soft mouthfeel, which is delicious. Brilliant.

Nip bottle, bought @ De Molen at the 1st BBF.
Pours pitch black in my glass. The head is velvety and thich, but still rather fizzy. Not quite beige, but somewhere between that and off-white. Stunning aroma. So much oak, so much malty sweetness. Roasted almonds, hazelnuts, ash, dark chocolate, still rather sweet. Some molasses. Light alcohol note. Low but prickly carbonation, mouthfeel is surprisingly light. Kinda velvety, but not really creamy. There are plenty of flavour though. Smoke, again molasses, light blackberry, viniousness, roasted malts, still a bit of roasted almonds. The oak probably gives it the relative lightness and it provides a fine, crafty tartness to the proceedings. Finish is vinious, dark chocolate, prunes and an unwillingness to let go of me. Just a perfectly crafted base beer in a good oak cask that sadly does it more harm than good. Especially in mouthfeel. Good, very good, nonetheless.

Bottle. Pretty dark, black pour, small tan head. Thick aroma with lots of port-like sweetness, rum and sugar. Also some spices and red wine. Subtly roasted feeling in general. Taste is more roasted, also has some wine and port, vanilla, chocolate and berries. A small amount of faint spices. Low carbonation, medium duration, big body. Very interesting and entirely lovable!

Sweet and smoky smell with hint of alcohol. Very dark, practically black color. Head is made of tiny bubles. Taste is great, absolutely fabulous. Obviously lots of malts has been poured to this beer, as well as hops. Theres many tastes that envolve. First strong and even sour alcoholic smoky taste. Soon after sweet taste followed by flowery ligth taste. Oh my god. Is this best Ive ever had, Im not sure but close call.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown with a small tan head. Nose is of stewed fruits and coffee. Coffee, chocolate, vanilla and even oak are present on the palate. The warming 11 % alcohol content is well masked, but is evident. This beer is simply put, amazing. Worth every cent of the price tag.

Bottle #155, thanks Dak. Pours dark brown/black, with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, red wine, wood, fruit, vanilla, and coffee. Flavor is roasted malt, red wine, vanilla, coffee, and chocolate. Smooth biody...not mucg sign of any alcohol. Wish the bottle was a little bigger, though.

Nip bottle from De Bierkoning. Pours black, with a small beige head. Upon opening the bottle theres a strong smell of red wine. In the glass theres oak, (red) wine, roasted malt, soy sauce. Taste is ever so slightly sweet with lots of roast/coffee and a little vinous tartness. Strong alcohol feel, medium bodied. Quite complex, gets better with every sip.

2010-08-03. Black body with a modest frothy brown head. 4+ Rich dark malt flavour, sweet base with tangy undertones, woody accents grow into the finish. Less complex than I expected, but a rich flavour. 7+ Aroma is rich, modest dark malt, tangy fruit overtones, very light wood character. Bit weak for the beer really. 7+ Smooth medium to full bodied palate. Very good but less impressive than I had hoped based on previous ratings. Wooden Cask at GBBF 2010

This black brew had the aroma of Fruit Loops and coffee.  It had a slightly oily palette that was a little thin.  It tasted like coffee and blueberries and was just a bit oxidized.  Has a lot of flavors of things I like to have for breakfast.

Another corker from De Molen. Black colour with a very small tan head. Not much carbonation going on in this one. As a result, the aroma is slightly restrained (considering what is to come on the palate), but there is quite a bit going on: wood, spice, vanilla, coffe and chocolate are all in there. The palate is similar, yet there is some booze in there with some nice hop resins too. Really explodes in your mouth! Upon smelling I was expecting something a bit restrained but this goes all out. Finely balanced finish with a nice bitterness. Superb!

Chocolatey aroma.  Pours black with no head.  The taste is chocolatey with a sweet alcohol finish.

Notes: On Barrel at the GBBF 10

Barrel spotting, GBBF 2010. WOW. Im finally trying this hotley anticipated beer my crew are desparate about. This is something astonishing. Excellent lacing; creamy and fluffy head, just a marvelous head, opaque colour, black tar in appearance, low particles, soft carbanation, coffee, delicate white Swiss chocolate, the authentic stuff, some really juicy subtleties going on in this beer. Really outstanding. I want this again! Thanks, Menno!

From the wood at GBBF 2010. Stunning. Black in colour with little head. Amazing aromas of plums and port, christmas pudding, chocolate, tobacco, coffee and lovely vanilla from the wood. I just kept sniffing and getting more and more layers. It fills the mouth beautifully, coating the tongue to let you savour it for ages. The taste is of dried fruit, port and that wonderful wood character holding it all together beautifully. I love this beer. It is perfectly balanced with just enough bitterness in the finish. If you ever have the chance, you must. Again, stunning.

Bottled. Thx Nisse666.
Black with a medium beige head.
Oaky vinous (a bit alcoholic) ND FRUITY WITH VANILLA.

Half of my Dave at GBBF 2010. Pitch black in colour. No head nor lace. Strong gone off sherry nose with biting hints of rotten nettles. It probably would make a great pesticide... Oily rocket fuel flavours which quite easily could take the skin of your tounge. Sour strong and tingly mouthfeel, with a tender painful truffle end. Weird and wacky and very dangerous!
Bottle. Black beer with a brown head. Woody, oily aroma, cocoa, chocolate and vanilla notes. Woody flavor, oily, pine and chocolate, cocoa, mint notes, some alcohol showing.

Deep amber-ruddy pour.  The nose is intensely fruity.  Lots of bourbon/cognac vineousness character and a rich plummy character.  A bit of light rum and dried figs.  There is a nice soft, sweet, fruity character.  A little bit of rich fruitiness.  Full-bodied but has a soft light fruitiness.  Really a lovely beer.  Intensely flavoured yet subtly integrated.

0.18 bottle at Petalax Beer Festival 2010, thank you very much oh6gdx! Black color with quickly vanishing head. The aromas of chocolate and perfumed alcohol. Very chocolatey, raisiny and coffeish flavor with fair amount of peppery alcohol. The chocolate and dark fruit character is nice but the alcohol aroma and flavor is not.

Papsoe hooks it up again, thanks Henrik. Bottle number 639 brewed Feb 2009 and filled October 2009. Cool little red-wax dipped 180 ml bottle. Pours a very dark brown hue with a medium creamy brown head. The aroma is much sweeter than the regular version; huge barrel, yeast, fruity. The flavor is great; sweet almost dry barrel, bourbon, creamy fruity flavors, light roast, milky chocolates. A medium mouthfeel. Very good. I slightly prefer the non BA version. It had more heavy roast, both were awesome.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2011 wow! dak comes through with a gem! nip bottle 1006 bottled 8/oct/2009 sampled on 3/21/2010.

walnut shade of black with a scant tan head.

the first thing i smell is peppery woodiness.... followed by roast, a little smoke, calcium or mineral water, yeast, chocolate, molasses and toasted coffee-like nuttiness. 

the flavor is all the aforementioned mixed with some vanilla and a mild bitterness on the finish. 

it has a medium body with a creamy rich mouth feel. 8/4/8/4/16/4.0

#385 bottled oct 8 2009. dak hooks it up on 1/9/11.
loads of tobacco, vanilla, green pepper, grape, ash, wood and vitamin pills.
sticky and delicious. sweeter than the regular.
8.5/4/8/4/16+

This one was really different. The body/carbonation felt like a mix between syrup and soy sauce. The flavors I got from it was malts, maple, a little dark chocolate. It was like no other beer that Ive had before. I really dont know what  else to say about it.

Bottle no 604 thx to HenrikS, 2010-06-05, tasting at Ekstedts
AR: sprity?, wood, coffey, bitter chocolate, 
AP: ebenholtz black, of white wee head
F: wood, coffey, bitter chocolate, bourborne vanilla, medium high bitterness

Another gem provided by Jan, poured into a snifter.  18cl bottle #434, bottled October 2009.

Pours dark, dark brown, not quite black, with a frothy beige head that recedes to a small cap and leaves some delicate lacing.

The aroma is sweet with chocolate malts and dark fruits.  There is a slightly smoked malt presence and some light coffee and a faint oak character.  A fairly light aroma for a RIS.

The taste really mirrors the aroma with a dominant caramel, vanilla and chocolate sweetness.  

The mouthfeel is light to medium bodied for an RIS with good carbonation.  Its a bit light on the feel overall though.

This is an excellent beer but its certainly on the lighter side of things for an RIS.  Extremely drinkable but not overly complex.

Bottle (18 cl), thanks Nisse666. Black with medium brown/beige head. Coffee and chocolate roasted aroma with some vanilla and green peppers. Full bodied and silky smooth. Well balanced, medium bitterness.

Bottle. Tasting at Ekstedt´s. Thanks to nisse666. Black colour with a brown head. Aroma of sweet malt, roastiness, chocolate, whisky cask, bourbon, booze, meat. Sweet and roasted flavor, with notes of coffee, alcohol, dark fruit, chocolate, whisky cask, some sourness. Dry finish.
Small bottle, thanks to Nisse666!On June 5, 2010Black color, brown head. Chocolate, malty, sweet scent. Smoke, sweet, alcohol, roasted taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness.

Bottle #1006 shared by Daknole at Hellbillys Shootout in Sosco Tasting.  Thanks Dak  never thought Id see this one around!  Pours midnight black with a chocolate colored  head.  The milk chocolate, burnt malt, dark fruits.  The taste is roast, ashy cocoa, coffee, dark fruits and burnt malt.  Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel.  Great beer.  Thanks again Dak!

18cl bottle at home. Pitch black pour, small tan head. Complex aroma with butter, alcohol, dark fruits, roasted malts, bourbon, leather, some sugar and a faint hint of coffee. Flavor is very rich, slightly sweet in the beginning with fruits like apple, pear and melon, some red wine, toffee, caramel and some faint coffee. Very rich and extremely well balanced. Quite lively carbonation completes an awesome brew.
Black of color with a nice beige head. An aroma of liqurice, port, tobacco, red berries,  dark fruits and some alcohol. A flavor of of wine, red berries, tobacco, wood, dry,

nip bottle thanks to bierkoning.  poured black with a beige head.  aroma was chocolate, fudge, bourbon??, and coffee with the flavor being pretty much the same.  medium body with low carbonation.  Thanks Edo for sending this my way.

Bottle trade with wavers1.  Terry, youre a God, and probably my favorite trading partner.  Thank you.  This beer is God-damn incredible.  Color is a brown-black with ruby highlights and no head.  Nose is rife with port, plum, strawberry, unbelievable malts, great character from the wood (which itself was imported from Elven Country) and a very vinous, ephemeral character.  Flavor is the fruit and wood mentioned above, topped off with a beautiful dark grape old port character that is just absurd.  Like a chocolatey, brandy-soaked Alexander the Grape.  Just unbelievably balanced and possibly the best wood-aged beer I have ever had.

Picobottle nr 247. Dark brown nearly black with medium brown head Aroma burned malts, hopps, weak alcohol notes from the barrelageing bourbon ?, chocolate, sugar. Taste Little hopp bite then burned malts and some sugar sweetness, prickless the tongue, faint notes of alcohol and bourbon from the barrel. A great beer, but I find it hard to find a difference between this one and an imperial stout ?

bottle thanks to ericandersnavy.  poured deep brown with a beige head.  nose is chocolate, roasted malts, chocolate, and wood.  nice on the palate, flavors of alcohol, chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla, and a nice finish.
Bottled 18cl. Bottle number 396. Alcoholic nose which is reminiscent of tequila. Really dissapointing.

(7oz nip bottle thanks to ericandersnavy) deep brown pour with light tan head. Nose of chocolate, toasted caramel. Taste of sweet chocolate, cocoa, raisins and other very dark fruits. Creamy and well carbonated finish.

Black with a red hue and a nice creamy brown head. Notes of dust, oil, soil, mocca, rubber and cocoa. The flavour is nicely balanced between an initial chocolate-like sweetnes and a finishing dusty bitterness. The alcohol is present, though. Good, but not as stunning as Hel & Verdoemenis.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, plums, raisin, vanilla, caramel, sugar and some alcohol. Good long finish.
bottle, thanks to ericandersnavy, muddy brown pour with tan foam, aroma of ashtray , coffee and raisins, flavors of spicy mole chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit, smooth finish

Bottle 574 Ruby brown color with no head. Aroma is very rich. Sweet, malty, caramel, chocolate and rich sweet fruit. Slightly roasted malts balance out the sweetness. Flavor is sweet, smooth, chocolate and fruit. Hides the abv pretty well. Thick full body.

(Bottle, courtesy of ericandersnavy)  Pours a murky brown body with a spare beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, herbs, cherry, and chocolate.  Flavor of chocolate, roasted malt, vinous, vanilla and herbs.

100th rate of this. 2009 bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours with a brown head over a deep brown body. Aroma of alcohol, vanilla, ash and chocolate. Taste is alcohol, nutty, toffee, brown sugar, alcohol, bitter, lightly vinous. Light bubbles and a bit thin.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2011 Pours dark, dark brown almost opaque with no head. It is not really black, but more dark brownish. A stunning appearance.
The aroma has lots of dark fruits, dates, figs, raisins, plums, a bit of cherry, little dark chocolate and a tiny hint of coffee, brown sugar and cinnamon. The aroma is very port wine-like. Amazing aroma!
The taste has the same dark fruits, and a bit of bitterness and sourness in the middle that suites the beer really good. The after taste has coffee, and a tiny bit of dark chocolate pop up every once in a while. Has some warming alcohol in the finish.
Medium carbonation, medium to large body. Oily texture sticks in the mouth.
A fantastic and complex beer, really really good.

Note to self: let it breathe for 30 minutes before starting drinking it. It needs time to decant.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2010 Bottle at home, thank you very much NoiZe! This one I will never find again probably. Saved it as my 150th rating, so it could rest some time before I opened the bottle. Bottle brewed at 19/02/2009 and bottled at 08/10/2009, nr. 48/1216. Very dark brown, about black liquid. Dark beige, almost brown head, not very big, but bigger then I expected, and it holds a good time. Very nice smell. Roastiness, chocolate, red fruits, coffee, really nice, smells like something for me. Nice taste of coffee, roastiness, dark fruits. Nothing overwhelming, even not the bitterness. Also not at the aftertaste. Really a nice surprise. Had some disappointments earlier from this brewer, but this is a beer that I like. Oily body, and good balance between the different tastes. Only the aftertaste misses some kind of boost. A bit sad the bottle was so small, and I had only 1.

Bottle from Beer Konig. Pours black with a nice foamy tan head. Aroma mostly of coffee with influence of heat. Medium plus body with creamy carbonation. Its almost stout. Lots of coffee and lots of smooth burnt malt. Strangely the heat isnt noticeable, except in the aroma. Finishes quite mellow.
chocolate, dark malt,brown, minimal head, medium bitterness, full body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,
Black and with a light-brown head,  Lots of pleasent aromas, malt, sweet caramel, grain. Flavor is heavy sweet. more dark notes, cohocotes, coffee, laqurice. Syrupy texture.

18cl bottle pours a watery, opaque black with a thin, creamy, tan head.  The porter aroma really comes through, sweet, sugary, oats.  Flavor is sweet, boozy, oats, brown sugar.  Finish is a little hot.
Sampled at RBWG 2010.  A very special thanks for this brew.  The pour is awesome. The flavor and aroma is an awesome combination of chocolate and coffee. This is an awesome beer.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2010 Bottle 18 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Bottle # 733. Pours pitch black with a smallish beige head. Aroma of hard roasted malts and a discreet woody touch - very subtle. Solid body with a surprising carbonation - is this force carbonated? ("NO", the brewer beermailed me!).  Hard roasted malts and vanilla - again with subtle wooden touches. Perfectly balanced. Quite some alcohol in the finish. 070410
Pours black with a small light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, oak, vanilla, vineous and chocolate. Flavour is roasted malt, malt acidic, alcohol, oak, vanilla and chocolate.

Very dark, lots of roast,  decent chocolate. Taste is slightly sweet, lightly bitter, heavy roast. Medium body is just a bit rough, moderate carbonation. Seriously, this is a decent beer, but not close to the ratings.

Bottle shared by daknole @ Hellbillys...thanks DAK!!!  Never thought Id get an opportunity to try this one.  Onyx pour produces a nice latte colored head.  Aroma is dark fruit and chocolate with peat, molasses, and roasted coffee.  Flavor is very well balanced with invisible alcohol.  Taste some black licorice, vanilla, and oak...pretty sweet but not cloying.  Velvety texture.
Bottle @ Alvinne proefzolder. Pours like black whisky, lots and lots of tears on the glasswork. Chocolate, malty and peated aromas dominate. Lots of alcoholwarmth. Very good.

Bottle. Pours nice black with a brown head. Chocolate very, berries,  sweet and alcohol.  Dessert like. Can a beer be too balanced? ves.

Fløska.Útsjónd: Dark brown with a nice creamy light brown head. Nøs: Sweet and roasty, nice maltiness, dark fruits, some port. Good mouthfeel indeed. Smakkur: Roasted malt, dark fruits, some wood and alcohol, mild chocolate, bit liquorice. Tasty smooth brew indeed.

Pours deep dark brown almost black complete opaque chocolate brown hues. Light beige head.  Thin lasting ring

Sweet bourbon alcohol aroma with roasted chocolate malt, caramel, oatmeal, toffee, and bourbon which doesnt overpower the other flavors. There is also some raisin, bourdeaux barrel, wood and vanilla hints in the nose.

Medium bodied with some sweet bourbon alcohol that is not overpowering with an excellent balance of chocolate malt, slight roast coffee, toffee, vanilla and earthy oak. Slightly vinous and sweet with a nice barrel presence. Delicious and incredibly quaffable. The high ABV is excellently masked.

Bottle.
Pours black with a small brown head.

Chocolate, berries, peated, sweet and alcohol.
Grapes, malt and alcohol. 
Heavy dessert like feeling.

Bottle shared by CaptainCougar.  Pours a brune body with a tan head.  A very hazy appearance.  Dark fruity tones, fruit esters, port wine, oak y and chalky vanilla accents.  Sweet with a modest warming and a sweet malty body.  Light chocolate and a touch of mint.  Nice.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2010 Wavers you rock bro! Pours a dark brown color with very little head.  Dried fruit, raisins, port, sherry, brown sugar aroma.  Flavor is rich and sweet with some prunes, raisins, caramel, honey and chocolate.  Nice damn beer.  Thanks Baker.
bottle shared by daknole. aroma is brown sugar candi yeast. flavor much the same. very balanced and a touch sour. good stuff.
bottle pours dark brown with a thin tan head.  Peaty brown sugar nose.  Sweet caramel malt and dark candied sugar flavors with what tastes like rye in the finish.  Solid.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2010 Bottle. Pours black with a small, but nice, golden head. I really like the booziness in the aroma. Sweet alcohol, milk chocolate, vanilla and grapes. The grape notes are not as welcome in the taste as in the aroma. The oaky mint/vanilla notes and the smokiness in the aftertaste are nice though. I would have liked the body a bit heavier to deal with all the complexity.

bottle shared by faroeviking.
Dark brown, smooth creamy light brown head.
Aroma is dry, sweet malts, roasted grains, brown sugar, wheaty. mild and quite smooth.
flavor is smooth, licorice, roasted grains, belgain caramel, extremely smooth and well balanced, tilted to the sweet side. pretty good tasting actually.
palate is silky smooth.

Bottled 180ml. -from bierkompass.de; Birthday gift from my girlfriend.
Bottle No. 616 of 1216. Pitch black coloured, small brown head, very pleasant chocolate nose. Roasted malt, dark chocolate and licorice with mild alcohol presence. Also dried fruits. Vinous finish. Despite high alcohol content highly drinkable brew. Great beer, pity that the bottle is soooo small!!!

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 110310.
Black with beige head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Flavor is roasted malt with smooth palate.

Tiny bottle at home. Pours an opaque black with a small beige head. Sweet with aromas of dried fruits and raisins. Also aromas of tobacco and some alcohol. Also hints of English liquirish. Gives plastic tank burbs. Some residual sugars. Medium bodied. Medium to soft carbonation. Long dried fruits finish.

nip courtesy of deflagro, thanks a ton! nice thick, dark brown pour with a thick creamy brown chocolate-milkshak- foam head that has surprisingly good retention. nice aroma that is very dougy and yeasty, notes heat and gunpowder, notes of citter cocoa, charcoal, vanilla and oak are pleasant. the mouthfeel is thick and chewy, nice and warming but not too much detectable heat, more of an afterburn. notes of tobacco, smoke, sweet yams, prunes, clove, cinnamon,and figs all show up. thick and sweet at first, slightly drying and bitter in the finish, very nicely balanced. vanilla extract notes mixed with a premium cigar and blackstrap molasses, yummy stuff! a nice strain of yeast, has nice lager notes present, but not overpowering.

Piccolo bottle (18cl). Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Fantastic powerfull heavy malty and fruity aroma. Plumb, coffee and chocolate notes. Powerfull bitter chocolate flavor. Some discreet nice coffee notes. Vanilla too. Long great finish. Fantastic experience.

Bottle. Pours a very dark beer with a lightbrown head. The aroma is bold with licorice, coffee and tobacco. The flavor is roasted, vanilla, oak, licorice and coffee. The palate is roasted. Overall a really good and complex beer.

Bottle kindly shared by plovmand, very appreciated! 
Pours black with a nice small and dense light brown head. 
Very vinous aroma with notes of dark fruits and roasted malt. 
The flavour is not as fruity as expected but dominated by roasted malt, coffee, alcohol and dark fruits with a hint of oak and liquorice. 
Nice creamy texture.

Bottle. Pitch black with a creamy longlasting tan head. The aroma is dark fruity, light roasted malt, alcohol and light chocolate. Very vinous. The flavour is warming alcoholic, dark fruit, light coffee, chocolate, oak, dried ripe fruit, light pepper. Very vinous and smooth.

Red wax dipped 18cl bottle, #634 of 1216 for this batch.  Brewed on February 19, 2009, bottled on October 8, 2009, and consumed in January 2010.  The pour yields a dark, hazy, chestnut to mahogany colored body.  A scant, light brown surface film recedes to a thin edge and leaves no lace.  Aromas are based in dark cocoa roast, quite earthy overall, with a good helping of toasted, vanilla laden oak, and a slightly odd, fruity, berry twang from the Bordeaux barrel.  Flavors delve deeper, again showing chocolate, but this time accompanied by loads of dark, figgy fruit.  Twangy, slightly tannic red wine notes work well as the counterpoint to the dark, roasty malts, while woody, toasted oak works to pull everything together.  The body is a little lighter than Id like, kind of roasty and slightly drying, with moderate, fine-bubbled carbonation.  A satisfying, alcoholic warmth creeps up on the finish, which lingers with smoldering dark fruit.  Interesting, nice brew.

Bottle. Black with a brown tha doesnt last long. Strong roasted aroma with some alcohol and the typical oaky notes. Lovely smooth flavour; chocolate, coffee, vanilla and hashish. Dry, almost astringent finish. Great beer!
Black pour, thin light tan head. Slightly hot, slightly lactic aroma, light roastiness. Nice taste, cocoa and roast, alcohol, raisin.
Thanks to Cheeseman, solan and berlanda.  Needs some air.  Hot and full of caramel.  Good.

Courtesy Bierkoning. Black/brown, tan carbonation. Rich, chocolatey malt, dark fruits, earthy barrel. Strong, sweet, barreled porter. Full body, smooth. Another excellent dark strong brew from De Molen.

Bottled. Pours out in a pitch black colour with a small creamy pale brown head. Rich aroma of wood, licorice, honey, burnt malts, black coffee, dark chocolate, port and prunes. Full-bodied with viscous notes of tar, licorice, wood, port, coffee, red apples, figs and raisins. Thick mouthfeel with low carbonation. Long chewy finish. salty licorice, coffee, dark chocolate, raisins, prunes and wood. Liquid art.

Bottle. 2009 vintage.

Dark brown with a medium-sized beige and fizzy head quickly fading away. Not really any lacings.

The smell is nice and deep. Lots of round mature fruit aromas, some edgy spices, toffee and caramel. Bog woody notes. Not very roasty. Hints if minerals as well. A very vinous smell that really grows on you. 

The taste is dominated by rich vinous fruit notes coupled with earth, spices, minerals and a hint of plastic. Salt licorice and wood. Smooth and sweet malts struggle to break through, together with aromas of chocolate, toffee and caramel. Hints of grape skin. The finish is spot on with a perfectly integrated note of warming alcohol, dry semi-tart fruit notes and grass. The taste is really aromatic from start to finish.

Full bodied and smooth with a dry finish. 

All in all, very good and very impressive. The crude description "tastes like a musty red wine blended with porter" would actually be quite fitting. The wine barrel character is really intense, very close to overpowering. I really enjoyed this one.

Poors black with a minimal brown head. Aroma is smooth of chocolate along with some fruity vinouse character. Flavor is also smooth with some dense chocolate sweetness and a mild roasted background. Highly drinkable and very smooth!

Bottled October 2009.

A - Pitch black with a thin sheet of cocoa head. No lacing.

S - Brown sugar, molasses, roasted malts, and cocoa. Theres also a smokey tobacco/leather smell with apparent alcohol.

T - Molasses, cocoa, malts, and alcohol. There hops are still present as well at 92IBUs

M/D - Mouthfeel is great, full body with light carbonation. Im very glad this bottle from De Molen was carbonated. Drinkability suffers due to the alcohol heat, it needs some time.

This beer was complex and interesting, but still a little too hot to fully enjoy. Im sure it would last a while in a cellar.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks Neiman. Black with a brown head. Chocolatey aroma with some coffee, some toasted bread and some wood. Sweet flavor with some wood, chocolate and caramel. Medium-full body and a silky mouthfeel.

Bottled at Monks Café Wallingatan, Stockholm.  Very black with small head. Rich roma of licorice, pear, butter and chocolate with honey and whisky coming through. Full bodied. Vinous and vastly complex with peatr-like calvados, butter and licorice. Salty finish with good bitterness. I may not be the greatest fan of this type of beers, but this is an awesome flavour bomb!
18cl, new exclusive Dutch brew Anno 2008, from Slijterij van Bergen Eindhoven, very complex Porter, balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

180mL Bottle #202 from Secret Santa and shared with Shawn: Nearly opaque with a small creamy head and okay lace. The aroma is quite interesting, a peaty iodine and almost fishy phenolic overtone that would be scotch like if not missing the charred smoky oak barrel. Some spicy and herbal hop, toast, leather, and fig esters. The taste is a far improvement over the nose, slightly bourbony with chocolate, vanilla, fig, plum, and earthy tones. Some medicinal and boozy notes upon the finish. The mouth feel is warming, sharp and astringent . Was a lot nicer once the phenolic character died down (or I got used to it). I wonder if there is a "house yeast" character from de Molen I find a bit off-putting in the beers I have had so far?

bottle shared by bbb63-  thanks mike.  pours a mruky pondwater brown.  Aroma is peat, scotch, tangy plum, booze, plus a weird medicinal paint thinnner like note.  flavor is a tangy, roasted dark chocolate.  A lot  bitterness to the taste,   like a bitter chocolate porter.  The aroma was interesting, but the paintlike note wasnt so hot.  interesting though.  curious how this would be with some age on it.

Its black with a light brown, creamy head. The aroma is vinous with notes of wood, roasted malt, dark fruit, vanilla, chocolate and light licorice. The flavor has a moderate sweetness and is vinous with notes of wood, roasted malt, vanilla, dark fruit, berries, chocolate and towards the end also light licorice. It is truly nice!

Bottle #806 poured by Glenn at Alvinne - thanks Glen!
Very dark maroon color with an edge head and some lacing.
Aroma of chocolate and bitter cocoa.
Flavor starts with milk chocolate then progresses to roasted espresso beans and vanilla, well-balanced.
Very good body.
Nice De Molen brew.

Bottle # 463. This is the best beer Ive had in a while. Pours pitch black with a creamy lasting brown head and lacings. Deep roasted malty with an incredibly vinous touch. Red Wine, chocolate, abit of vanilla and coffee. Vinous, smooth and full bodied. Great balance and great flavor. Light warmth.  Dammnn,  this is a top tenner.

Bottled. Pitch black coloured. Light brown dense head. Aroma of roast, sugar, fruits, coffee and berries. Light vanilla as well. Flavour of wood, berries, vanilla, brown sugar, herbs, light caramel and vague roast. Medium to full bodied. Ends on a sweet, quite syrupe and vanilla dense note. Light alcohol warmth on lips and palate. Quite nice.

Dark brown, close to black with a small but compact light brown head that leaves some nize lazing after a swirl in the snifter. Aroma is extremely vinous and woody with notes of various berries and fruit, vanilla, caramell and toffe. Flavour is similar but even more intense belive it or not.. Its extremely fruity and mature with a almost red-wine like character with additional notes of caramell, light chocolate and coffe. Ends on a mature longlasting, slightly alcoholic (warming) and sweet note with the barrel character lingering forever. Body is big, almost chewable and creamy smooth.

Flaske: Åbner med et pift hvilket er beroligende. Farven er sort med et minimalt skumhoved. Duften er meget alkoholisk med en svag bourbon note. Smagen er kraftig bourbon på en uraffineret måde. Base øllen må sådan set have været ok, men alt drukner i bourbon. Ikke nogen fantastisk øl, der dog alligevel sniger sig op på over 3 bare fordi.

Bottle (18ml) at home. Black - brown head. Chocolate, oakey, wood, roasted, high sweetness, licorice, sharpness, coffee, spicy, vineous, high malty, powerfull, light vanilla, light alcoholic. Very nice.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2012 5th August 2008. GBBF. Roasty malt - smooth and not too bitter. Good sourish whiskey like note but not peaty or smokey. Smooth ending with a touch of sherry. Lots of warmth. 4th August 2009GBBF. Opaque black beer. Soft palate. Rich and slightly spicy dark malt. A little unsweet wood and repressed chocolate. Less sweet and sherry like than last year.6th August 2010. GBBF. Opaque black beer with a little brown suddy head. Soft smooth palate. Very complex beer. Soft chocolate, red fruits, dark fruits, traces of whisky and brandy. A litlle coffee. Finishes smooth. Best year yet for this now GBBF regular! 3rd August 2011GBBF. Barrel. GBBF would not be GBBF without this annual treat! Opaque black beer, bubbly tan head. Light and fresh dark malt. Seltzer like minerals, trace of herbs. Rich chocolate malt with a mildy sour woody tang. Finishes semi dry. Marvelous beer!

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2010 1. Stillage From a Wooden Cask at the GBBF, Earls Court 04/08/2009
Big roast aroma. Black and strong in alcohol with a crisp and slightly bitter warming chocolate finish.

3. Stillage from a Wooden Cask at the GBBF, Earls Court 05/08/2010
Whisky roast aroma. Beige head. Black strong in alcohol and rich on the palate with a bitter warming coffee roast finish.
Bottle @ Borefts Beer Festival 2009. Black colour, beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, fruits. Flavour of chocolate, dark fruits, roasted malts. Very good beer!
Bottle at BBF. Black body with small head. Nose of malts and chocolate. Really nice, rich and dark taste of chocolate, coffee and dark fruits. Well-balanced. Very, very good.

Bottle at 1st Borefts Beer Festival at De Molen.
Black coloured with a small beige head.
Roasted aroma of dark chocolate with notes of port wine and whisky.
Roasted flavour of dark chocolate and port wine with notes of dried fruits.
Dry roasted and warming alcoholic finish.

Bottled @ BBF. Cloudy brownish color, medium off-white head. Aroma of chocolat and coffee, but also fruity red wine. Perfect balance in taste between the roasted coffee from the tsarina esra and the vinous notes of the barrel aging. Awesome stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2012 On draft at 1st Borefts Beer Festival, Bodegraven. Completely dark appearance, beige head. Very complex nose, chocolate, coffee, malts. Very complex flavor, some sweetness, nicely balanced. I like it eeven a lot more than the regular version (altough that one was very young). Absolutely fantastic. Re-rate: bottled, number 622 bottled Feb 19th 2009, sampled Dec 2012. I didnt think it was possible, but it actually got even better after 3.5 years. Wow...

Bottled at Borefts Bier Festival, De Molen. Black with a beige head. Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, some coffee and dark fruits. Flavour is all of the above, nice chocolate and vanilla sweetness ending in a nice soft bitter finish. Fullbodied. Outstanding.

Wow. Bottle from our Mes, yet again fine work mate. Black as Tevezs heart, with elbow patch brown head. Aroma is head swimmingly awesome and heart achingly lovely. Like a dustbin lid sized chocolate cake. Rich but smooth flavour. Perfect mouthfeel. The oak aging gives a hint of vanilla, almost bordering on coconut. Almost liquor like. Has a wine like quality somewhere in the huge finish, not in the palate er somewhere else. Lovely. Will definitely have to re-rate in a larger quantity if I get the chance. And Ill certainly be looking for it.
Cask at GBBF 2009: chocolate milk, dark chocolate, cocca butter, dried fruits, weak sourness, very very rich, thick body, full flavored, amazing beer,
Chocolate and fine cigars, washed down with eyebrow-raising quantities of schnapps and cherry brandy, its an entire christmas holiday condensed into beer. I dont care that it is August.

Opaque black, small steady tan head. Lots of vanilla and whisky in the nose. Full-bodied. Flavor is dominated by roasted malts, vanilla, whiskey, some peat. Its a bit sweeter than toasted. You find Tsarina Esra base here easily. Good beer ;)
From cask at GBBF 2009. Very dark brown, small creamy capuccino head. Nice fruity, rummy coffee aromas and flavours, good tartness, bitter aftertaste.  Soft as velvet. A treat for the senses.
Black with a small off-white head. Aroma of malt, molasses and oak. Sweet and roasted flavour, with a smooth alcohol note. Lasting bitter finish of roasted malt and tannin.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 Bottle 70cl. Brewed 16/2 - 08 and bottled 9/7 08. One of the only fourty bottles that this rarity is filled on. Had the chance to taste this in the real sorrunding - and it couldnt be better. Sitting in de Molens warehouse, an old cheese storage house which has a naturaly cool temperature and an extreem coolnes to it. Situated next to the charming canals of Bodegraven on an summer afternoon. Sitting there among all the bottles and winebarrels from de Molen and taste a lovely and interesting beer like this is priceless. Thanx a lot Menno.
The pour is darkbrown almost black. The aroma is saaz-hopped with nose of vinegar, apples, plum - a little lactose, english laqurice and alcohol.
The taste is very complex with a nice sourness and tempered alcohol taste. There is notes of laquirice, ashes and chocolate.
The palate is picking your tounge and is pretty dry with a loong lasting vinoes finish with notes from the bourdoux-barrels and some bitterness.
Very nice.

Cask @ GBBF 2008. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a malty dark chocolate aroma with some hints of licorice, dark fruit and vanilla. Slightly sweetish malty vinous fruity dark fruit flavor with hints of caramel, chocolate and licorice flavor. Also some hints of vanilla. Has a sweetish warming malty caramel and dark fruit finish with hints of licorice and vanilla in the aftertaste. Very nice.
Bottle, at LCRBM 2008, s Hertogenbosch, Netherlands  Black body, lightly brown head.  Brilliant aroma of strong malts, fruit, port. Heavily bitter, lightly sweet flavour.  Very intense and nice.

Bttle LCRBM08. Solid sweet-fruity - dried fruits - nose with molasses and leather. Robust sweet-bitter flavour, full bodied. Lingering, full, fruity and tobacco-like finish with a bitter touch. Impressive fizz.....

Bottle @ LCRBM 2008. Aroma has chocolate, roasted malts with some fruitiness, prunes and wood/bourbon. Black coloured beer with a beige head. The taste is sweet with some slight bitterness. It has roasted malts, chocolate, bourbon/sherry, dark fruits, some vanilla and licorice. Really marvelous beer.

Bottle @ LCRBM 08: Poured a thick black color with a beige to brown color head. The aroma is roasted malts, fermented fruit, spice, and chocolate. Taste was simply devine with a chocolate and roasted malt, there is a nice mix of alcohol and fruits. These off set the sweet and make it very well balanced and tasty for sure.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2009 I couldnt imagine any other beer for rating # 5000. So here it is. Bottle, kindly provided by Menno. Dark chocolate, raisin, oak and plums in the aroma. Sweet raisinny flavor with porto, oak, plums, dark chocolate and fairly well hidden alcohol. Vanilla and hops in the aftertaste. The young girl (somehow I find Tsarina Esra a very feminime beer!) has developed into a beautiful, strong, well developed woman with a lot of power and complexity. 
I will probably never forget this beer for the rest of my life...

Bottled: 2009 version. Bordeaux barrel and you can notice that! Vinous aromas next to the coffee, dark chocolate, figs, raisinny and coffee notes you will find in the standard Tsarina Esra. Low on carbon. Powerful yet deceptively drinkable. Some alcohol in the finish. Once again a magic liquid.

Bottle@LCRBM08. A black colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma is gentle with roasted malts. There is chococlate with some coffee. Also hints of dark fruits. The taste of pure chocolate with a little bitter coffee. Dark fruits like overripe prunes with raisins. As aftertaste chocolate with prunes. Great beer.

LCRBM08: 75 cL bottle, courtesy of Menno. Pours pitch black and with a dense chocolate brown head. Aroma is smooth and roasted, chocolate, wineous and spiced, very inviting aroma. Smooth and wineous flavoured to a dense roasted malt base with notes of chocolate on the back of the tongue. Nicely decending into the finish with a mild warmth and smoothness. btw: makes a fantastic blend with 3 Fonteinen Hommage :)

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2009 Tastingsession LCRBM08.Black colored brew. Sweet aroma, bourbon, sherry, nice. Flavor is very smooth. Bourbon, sweet syrup, butter, vanilla. Ends with the tones of dark chocolate, some liquorice. Good balanced. I really love this beer. I wonder what aging can do for this beer. Going to drink it again on a lucky, lucky day. 

Tasted again at the first, great, Borefts Beer Festival 2009 @ De Molen. Just perfect.

Small yellow-brown head over near-black beer. Fully estery, alcohol, brandy and lots of vanilla. Vanilla returning strong in the mouth, with sweet brandy, some liquorice, dark- and milkchocolate. Despite all these major flavours out in force, it keeps a really excellent balance. Full bodied, of course, with a viscous and creamy MF to boot. Beautiful beer - just beautiful.

Cask (gravity) @ Great British Beer Festival, GBBF 2008, Earls Court, London, England SW5.This to celebrate my rating #4900 on ratebeer. Clear dark black color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly dimimshing, beige head. Aroma is heavy malty, roasted, caramel, chocolate, cream chocolate, licorice, vanilla, alcohol. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long long duration. Body is full, texture is oily - creamy - syrupy and so smooth, carbonation is flat. This is a beer that Mrs. fonefan loves and me also. It is so powerfull and complex - balanced - impressive.. Very very nice .. It is not for lager boys....  ;o)) It was my first and last beer the first 2 days on GBBF, Mrs fonefan did not drink much else the second day ... ;o)) Lovely work Menno, you are one of the best ! (050808)
GBBF, Trade Day, 2008 Gravity cask (oak). Musty and musky - touches of warm plastic. Wonderful aroma. Warm, soft mouthfeel - very rich and coating. Warm treacle. A gorgeous beer.

Giant oak cask, BSF at the GBBF. Shiny black, a bit of tan head. Very clean bright bourbon nose, french toast with a generous dose of maple syrup, mahogany. Buttery soft roast flavor, rummy vanilla fudge, chocolate cake. Thick and sweet, but not sticky. A proper Imp. (Thanks Tom, for the rest of your neglected glassful. )

Cask at GBBF someone is goign to get angry at me here. I asked for just a sample of this as i knew i wouldnt like it however the guy insisted that i must buy a glass as "its the best beer here
". The blackness and of the pour lets me know im about to get upset. The aroma is cheap blanco taquila, intence alcohol, burnt and bitter, from the aroma alone i was actually more upset than i expected to be. The taste is soo intence and off putting that i managed about 20mls before i gave the glass to doppleganger. I just couldnt get past the taquila aspect of it and so for me its completly undrinkable.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2008 Cask, 11% at GBBF08. Good creamy vanilla aroma. Black colour, very small light brown head. The flavour is very powerful, roasted, vinous, liquorice, and a good amount of alcohol and vanilla. Citric hoppiness. Citric finish with burning and rough alcohol.

Served from a large wooden barrel at the international bar (bsf), GBBF 08. Inviting aroma of sweet caramel. Vinous taste with warming chocolate developments, and some peaty hints to a lingering finish. Light brownish head over a dark brown coloured body. Very good, indeed, but a third pint glass was enough at the time (05.08.2008)

(Cask at GBBF, London, 5 Aug 2008) Black colour with brief, beige head. Roasted, malty nose with notes of wood, dark fruit, raisins and prunes. Roasted, malty taste with lots of wood character, dried fruit, raisins, vanilla and lots of liquorice. Long, vinous finish dominated by wood and liquorice. Warming and very nice.

Served from the oak cask in which it had been aged, at the GBBF 2008. Room temperature, gravity dispense. Pitch black colour, minimal head. Intense aroma of tar, woodwork, coffee, liquorice and alcohol. Intensely roasty flavour with coffee, alcohol, tar, liquorice and dark bitter chocolate. Pretty impressive, but certainly not easy drinking.

Cask. Low and quickly disappearing fluffy yellow head. Black is the body indeed. Coffee caramel hosp alcohol aroma. Flavor of strong coffee with hops bitterness in a good balance. Low carbonation, long aftertaste.

A Mes rate: From a HUGE wooden cask at GBBF.Black with a thin but very stable tan head, good lace and awesome bubbles when swilled. A very good looking beer. Amazing roasty chocolate aroma that is full of freshly ground coffee and some awesome barrelly alcohol. Strong bourbon notes but not at all over done. This is how barrel aging should be done. The flavour carries on in an almost equally incredible fashion. The oak is a little more apparent and somehow the chocolate has become even richer and darker and moved on into the 100% cocoa category. Superb roasted nut and oaky booze finish. Tart and full of action. This is just an incredible beer. My first of the festival and my last of the first day and my last of the second day too. I could not get enough. I know someone who was even more into it than me however. A certain Mrs Fonefan drank nothing but this on day two. She somehow remained impressively sober too. Bloody brilliant!

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - GBBF2008. A dark brown coloured beer.  Big alcohol on the nose including a rummy feel.  Thick gloopy alcohol flavours.  Vinuous to a fault.  Notes of bourbon it seems.  Very full bodied and tasty.

Wooden cask, GBBF 08. Jet black, thin shortlived beige head and low condition. Chocolate and bitter coffe beans, some fruitiness and a hint of spirits in the nose, full sweetness in the mouth initially but becoming woody and earthy with a slight bitterness developing, slight fruity spiciness in the finish but a lingering woody earthiness takes over with some retronasal whisky spirit notes.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008 TK2 notes Cask at GBBF 2008 ... Deep black ... light swet vanilla malt nose ... rich roasts malts ... bit too much spirit ... quite a lot of vanilla. Tk1 notes to follow when i find them...3.9
TK1 ...Deep black ... little spirit in nose ... rich sweet juicy toffeee and vanilla ... Some chocolate and a little spirit warming 4.1.

Cask at GBBF 2008   Pours black with a thin rim of tan bubbles sticking to the edge. This has a real deep bitterness but backed up with some citrussy hops. This is lovely thick complex sweet chocolate, coffee but also quite softened because of the oak ageing nice vanilla pushing through, a lovely beer that is just a bit too much for me but I can see why others loved this.

Great big wooden cask at GBBF 08 :) Pure black, still. Long before you get the beer into your mouth, you know this is going to command respect. The nose has stewed fruits, wood smoke, salty liquorice, coffee, molasses and malt. On the tongue, cocoa, dark fruits and tarry flavours are apparent. It’s so intense, the aroma stings your nose as you swallow. The oily texture coats the mouth and it slips down smoothly. A beer to drink slowly and give your full attention to.

Cask, GBBF 08.  Near black with a small beige head.  Aromas are vinous with dark molasses and tobacco.  Earthy with light spices and liquorice herbal notes.  Flavours are sweet and earth with spices.  Fruity and vinous with warming alcohol. Smooth on the palate.  Fantastic.

Cask at GBBF 08.  From a great big cask just like the one in the photo.  Vanilla hits you first.  Its an oily impy stout in the mouth.  It’s a very intense beer, makes the hall go quiet and focusses you in onto this beer.  Alcohol isn’t obvious in the mouth, but blows your legs away.  This really is stunning.  Strong, overwhelming and great.  Drinkability?  Perhaps not all the time, but as a finishing beer?  Oh boy, one of the best.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2009 Cask at GBBF 08. Some said this was best of the festival. Very dark brown. Sweet buttery caramel aroma.
